newsitem.title: MACAU: Air Macau names China's Li Keli as CEO.
newsitem.headline: Air Macau names China's Li Keli as CEO.

text.p: Air Macau said on Tuesday it had appointed Li Keli of the Civil Aviation Administration of China, the mainland's aviation regulator, as its chief executive officer.

"Li Keli's appointment was unanimously approved by Air Macau's executive committee on Monday, and the appointment will take effect on February 1," executive committee president Leonel Miranda told Reuters.
Li's last post was deputy director of the CAAC's international affairs department, Miranda said.
The flag carrier of the Portuguese-administered enclave earlier said its Singaporean CEO, Ng Kian-wah, left the airline on December 31 after completion of his contract.
Air Macau is 51 percent held by CAAC unit China National Aviation Corp's Air China.
On January 9, Air Macau said it had posted an operating loss of 60 million patacas (US$7.5 million) in calendar 1996, its first full year of operation. Turnover was 650 million patacas.
It said 665,000 passengers had flown on 5,700 flights to and from six destinations last year.
Air Macau flies daily fom Macau to Beijing, Shanghai and Xiamen in mainland China, and Taipei and Kaohsiung in Taiwan. It also flies three times a week to Bangkok.
